Modules¶

Tropical cyclone detection and tracking¶

persistence_functions.get_persistence(state_file, out_file, seasons={'DJF': {'index': 3, 'months': [12, 1, 2]}, 'JJA': {'index': 1, 'months': [6, 7, 8]}, 'MAM': {'index': 0, 'months': [3, 4, 5]}, 'SON': {'index': 2, 'months': [9, 10, 11]}}, overwrite=True)[source]¶

This function reads a state field created by temp_anomaly_to_ind() or precip_to_index() and finds persistent periods for these statesself. It uses optimized_period_identifier()

Parameters:
  • state_file (str) – filepath of a state file. This file needs to have a variable ‘state’ with -1 and 1 for the two different states. This file can be created by temp_anomaly_to_ind() or precip_to_index()
  • out_file (str) – filepath of a period file
  • seasons (dict, default=`{'MAM':{'months':[3,4,5],'index':0}, 'JJA':{'months':[6,7,8],'index':1}, 'SON':{'months':[9,10,11],'index':2}, 'DJF':{'months':[12,1,2],'index':3}}``) – dictionnary used to cluster detected periods into seasons. If no seasonal analysis is required use seasons={‘year’:{‘months’:range(12),’index’:0}}
  • overwrite (bool) – overwrites existing files
persistence_functions.optimized_period_identifier(ind)[source]¶

This function identifies persistent periods using collections. It isn’t a straight foreward implementation but runs faster than period_identifier()

Parameters:ind (np.array) – array containing -1 and 1 corresponding to two state
Returns:pers – array of the same length as ind containing the length of identified periods. Periods of state -1 are have negative lengths. The period length of a period is placed in the center of the period. All other values are 0.
Return type:np.array
persistence_functions.period_identifier(ind)[source]¶

Straight foreward period identifier. Missing values cut periods.

Parameters:ind (np.array) – array containing -1 and 1 corresponding to two state
Returns:pers – array of the same length as ind containing the length of identified periods. Periods of state -1 are have negative lengths. The period length of a period is placed in the center of the period. All other values are 0.
Return type:np.array
persistence_functions.precip_to_index(in_file, out_file, var_name='pr', unit_multiplier=1, threshold=0.5, overwrite=True)[source]¶

Classifies daily precipitation into ‘wet’ and ‘dry’ days based on a threshold

Parameters:
  • anom_file (str) – filepath of a daily precipitation file. The variable that is read in can be specified with var_name.
  • out_file (str) – filepath of a state file
  • var_name (str) – name of the variable read in anom_file
  • threshold (float,default=0.5) – threshold used to differentiate between wet and dry days
  • unit_multiplier (float,default=1) – factor to multiply daily precipiation with to get mm as units
  • overwrite (bool) – overwrites existing files
persistence_functions.temp_anomaly_to_ind(anom_file, out_file, var_name='tas', seasons={'DJF': [12, 1, 2], 'JJA': [6, 7, 8], 'MAM': [3, 4, 5], 'SON': [9, 10, 11]}, overwrite=True)[source]¶

Classifies daily temperature anomalies into ‘cold’ and ‘warm’ days using the season and grid-cell specific median as threshold

Parameters:
  • anom_file (str) – filepath of a temperature anomalies file. The variable that is read in can be specified with var_name.
  • out_file (str) – filepath of a state file
  • var_name (str) – name of the variable read in anom_file
  • seasons (dict, default=`{'MAM':{'months':[3,4,5],'index':0}, 'JJA':{'months':[6,7,8],'index':1}, 'SON':{'months':[9,10,11],'index':2}, 'DJF':{'months':[12,1,2],'index':3}}``) – dictionnary used to cluster detected periods into seasons. If no seasonal analysis is required use seasons={‘year’:{‘months’:range(12),’index’:0}}
  • overwrite (bool) – overwrites existing files

This part of the documentation shows the full API reference of all public functions.
